instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3492: What is 820-3492? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.SYS_ONEWIRE: What is SYS_ONEWIRE? This is a bidirectional communication line between the system management controller(SMC) and the charger that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC. This must be working for the light to come on on the magsafe charger. .
definitions.ADAPTER_SENSE: What is ADAPTER_SENSE? This is a line between the onewire circuit and the magsafe charger where the magsafe charger can talk to the SMC(system management controller) on the SYS_ONEWIRE line..
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.SMC_RESET: What is SMC_RESET? SMC_RESET is not a signal, it is an abbreviation for “SMC_RESET_L”, which is the signal someone is referring to when they type “SMC_RESET”  "SMC_RESET_L is a signal that resets the SMC when it is low(this is what the “_L” prefix means), and lets the SMC out of reset mode when it is high. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.820-3462: What is 820-3462? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..

Seems like there are multiple problems here, lets start with the obvious; <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3492</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> is not a valid number...

Was this liquid? I suspect crap under SMC or dead SMC

Finally had time to mess with this board again.  I reballed the smc and now have:

<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> - 3.4v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3492</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no orange light
threads.message:
1) What is the resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?

2) What is the resistance between pins 17/18 on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>? Measure at the pins. This should be around 2-3.

3) What is the resistance between pins 27/28 on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>? Measure at the pins. This should be around 20. 

4) What is the voltage on pin 2 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>? This should be charger voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3492</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no orange light
threads.message:
1- Black probe to ground - ..6Mohm
2- 17/18 - 3ohm
3- 27/28 - 20 ohm
4 - 16V

What do those four 17/18 27/28 do so i know for future use.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3492</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no orange light
threads.message:
Do you have a green light with this now? 

17/18 and 27/28 are part of the current sensing circuit. If it can't tell how much current the battery(27/28) and the charger(17/18) are using, it turns off the machine.

Those values read normally.

1) Are you getting a green light yet? 
2) If you short pins 10 and 11 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, do you get 12v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?

This is all pointing to bad soldering around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> so far.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3492</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no orange light
threads.message: I've replaced the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> twice now.  Once a while back and once yesterday.   I'll check the values and let you know.  I've triple checked to make sure soldering is good but still no green light though.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3492</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no orange light
threads.message:
still no light.
shorted the pin 10 and 11 together and still 1.2v on ppbus

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3492</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no orange light
threads.message:
1) What voltage do you get on pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7080</RESISTOR>?

2) What voltage do you get on pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R7080</RESISTOR>?

3) What voltage do you get on pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7085</RESISTOR>?

4) What voltage do you get on pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R7085</RESISTOR>?

5) Does <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> go up if you remove F7040? What do you get on pin 1 of F7040 if you remove F7040?

All signs still point to badly soldered <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> or bad <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> from what I see.

threads.message:

now i have ppbus voltage of 12.25, but still no light.

voltage of 7080 - 16.07 / 15.93
voltage of <RESISTOR>R7085</RESISTOR> - 16.61 / 6.76

<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> - 3.4v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3492</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no orange light
threads.message: SMC is bad. Reflow to see if that fixes, if not then replace. 12.23v <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> means it is not communicating with the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>. When the SMC is communicating with the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> will be 12.56v. The SMC is also responsible for the green light, as <SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> is the data line upon which it talks to the battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3492</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no orange light
threads.message: I have already reballed the smc.  I guess i'll just order a dead board now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3492</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no orange light
threads.message: Reballing the existing bad SMC will not fix it, it is like kicking a dead employee and asking him to work. Get a new SMC, the same way if your employee died you would find a new one..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3492</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no orange light
threads.message:
Okay sorry for bringing this back from the dead but i finally had a moment to install new smc.  Now have:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.56
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> - 3.372
PP3V42 - 3.404
<SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> -3.383
<SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> - 3.383

I also noticed that TP[1]<SIGNAL>DCINVSENS_EN_L</SIGNAL> was gone so I ran a wire from <TRANSISTOR>Q5480</TRANSISTOR> to <RESISTOR>R5481</RESISTOR>.  do i need to run it anywhere else?

I still have no fan spin :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3492</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no orange light
threads.message: Ok so you made some progress! Voltage on <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>? Check you rails in order like normal to see what is missing.
